newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Woodside says Cossack oil disconnects.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Woodside says Cossack oil disconnects.

text.p: Woodside Petroleum Ltd on Tuesday confirmed the Cossack Pioneer oil platform had disconnected from its offshore moooring in the Indian Ocean to flee the path of cyclone Rachel.

The rig was disconnected at around 1100 GMT (10.00 p.m. Sydney time) on Monday and immediately headed in a northwesterly direction ahead of Rachel, which is taking a southwesterly path down the Western Australia coast, a Woodside spokesman told Reuters.
The Cossack Pioneer pumps crude oil and gas from the Wanaea and Cossack fields on the North West Shelf of the Indian Ocean.
Production has been averaging about 90,000 barrels a day.
Rachel should generate winds with gusts of up to 180 km per hour as the cyclone passes close to the coastal community of Port Hedland around 0400 GMT (12.00 p.m.), the Bureau of Meteorology said.
A warning for a category three cyclone is current for coastal areas between the towns of Wallal and Onslow, including Dampier, Wickham, Roebourne, Karratha and Port Hedland, the bureau said.
At 0100 GMT (9.00 a.m.), Rachel was 75 km north of Port Hedland and was moving west-south-west at 20 km per hour toward the Western Australian coast, the bureau said.

Equal partners in the North West Shelf are units of The Broken Hill Pty Co Ltd, The British Petroleum Co Plc, Japan Australia LNG (MiMi) Pty Ltd, a partnership of Mitsui & Co Ltd and Mitsubishi Corp, Chevron Corp, Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Woodside.
